claim: Drinking excessive water can lead to hyponatremia

supporting.text: Hyponatremia is a medical condition caused by abnormally low sodium levels in the blood, which can result from excessive water intake diluting sodium concentrations.

attacks.text: Hyponatremia is a medical condition caused by abnormally low sodium levels in the blood, which can result from excessive water intake diluting sodium concentrations.
Hyponatremia is extremely rare in healthy individuals and typically only occurs in specific contexts like endurance sports or medical conditions.
Even in endurance athletes, hyponatremia is preventable with proper electrolyte management, making excessive water intake alone an insufficient cause.
The human body has effective regulatory mechanisms (e.g., kidney function, thirst response) that normally prevent excessive water intake from causing hyponatremia.
These regulatory mechanisms can be overwhelmed by extreme water consumption (e.g., >1L/hour for multiple hours), creating risk even in healthy individuals.

supporting.text: The kidneys have a limited capacity to excrete water, and consuming water beyond this capacity can lead to water retention and hyponatremia.

attacks.text: The kidneys have a limited capacity to excrete water, and consuming water beyond this capacity can lead to water retention and hyponatremia.
Most healthy individuals can excrete large volumes of water without risk of hyponatremia, as their kidneys adapt to increased intake.
Even in healthy individuals, extremely rapid water consumption (e.g., >1L/hour) can overwhelm renal excretion capacity and cause hyponatremia.
Hyponatremia primarily occurs in pathological states (e.g., SIADH) rather than from normal water consumption patterns.
Endurance athletes and psychiatric patients with polydipsia frequently develop hyponatremia from excessive water intake without pre-existing pathology.

supporting.text: Athletes who drink large amounts of water without adequate electrolyte replacement are at risk of developing exercise-associated hyponatremia.

attacks.text: Athletes who drink large amounts of water without adequate electrolyte replacement are at risk of developing exercise-associated hyponatremia.
Most athletes are aware of the risks of overhydration and follow guidelines for electrolyte replacement, making hyponatremia rare in practice.
Studies show that even educated athletes can misjudge hydration needs during prolonged events, leading to documented cases of hyponatremia.
Exercise-associated hyponatremia primarily occurs in extreme endurance events, not typical athletic activities.
Marathons and Ironman competitions report consistent hyponatremia cases annually, proving its relevance beyond theoretical risk.

supporting.text: Clinical guidelines recommend against excessive water intake, particularly in situations where sodium loss is already elevated, to prevent hyponatremia.

attacks.text: Clinical guidelines recommend against excessive water intake, particularly in situations where sodium loss is already elevated, to prevent hyponatremia.
Most people do not consume excessive water in normal daily conditions, making the risk of hyponatremia extremely rare for the general population.
Even in normal conditions, certain individuals (e.g., endurance athletes, those on specific medications) can still develop hyponatremia from moderate overhydration.
Sodium loss is not always clinically detectable, so guidelines are overly cautious and may discourage necessary hydration in some cases.
Medical guidelines account for undetectable sodium loss by recommending individualized fluid intake assessments rather than blanket restrictions.

supporting.text: Hyponatremia from excessive water intake is well-documented in medical literature, with cases ranging from mild symptoms to life-threatening cerebral edema.

attacks.text: Hyponatremia from excessive water intake is well-documented in medical literature, with cases ranging from mild symptoms to life-threatening cerebral edema.
Hyponatremia due to excessive water intake is extremely rare in healthy individuals with normal kidney function.
Even in healthy individuals, prolonged excessive water intake (e.g., water-drinking contests) can overwhelm renal excretion capacity and cause hyponatremia.
Most documented cases of water-induced hyponatremia involve special populations like endurance athletes or psychiatric patients with compulsive water drinking.
The special populations mentioned represent significant portions of at-risk groups, making this a clinically relevant concern beyond rare edge cases.
